Definition: A sequence of characters used by the sponsor to uniquely identify the study.
An abbreviation for a collection of observations, with a topic-specific commonality.
Notes: 2-character abbreviation. The domain abbreviation is also used as a prefix for variables to ensure uniqueness when datasets are merged.

Definition: A sequence of characters used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.
A sequence of characters used to uniquely identify a group of subjects that have been pooled together.
Notes: Used for results that are not assignable to a specific subject.

Definition: A sequence of characters used by the sponsor to uniquely identify a specific device.

Notes: Sponsor-defined identifier for a non-host organism. This variable should be populated with an intuitive name based on the identity of the non-host organism as reported by the lab.

Definition: A sequence of characters used to uniquely identify a fetus associated with a maternal subject, for a particular prenatal evaluation.

Notes: Identification of a focus of study-specific interest on or within a subject or specimen as called out in the protocol for which a measurement, test, or examination was performed. The value in this variable should have inherent semantic meaning.
Examples: A drug application site (e.g., "Injection site 1", "Biopsy site 1", "Treated site 1"), or a more specific focus (e.g., "OD" (right eye), "Upper left quadrant of the back")

Definition: A number used in combination with the identifier of the subject of the observation to uniquely identify a record within a domain.
Notes: May be any valid number (including decimals) and does not have to start at 1. Datasets that do not contain subject data, such as the Trial Summary (TS) domain and the Device Tracking (DT) domains, use --SEQ as a sequence number to ensure uniqueness within the dataset.

Definition: A sequence of characters used to uniquely identify related records for a subject within a domain, or related parameters in the Trial Summary (TS) dataset.
Notes: See also Section 5.1.6, Trial Summary Information and Section 5.1.7, Challenge Agent Characterization.

Definition: A sequence of characters used to uniquely identify a source of information.
Examples: A lab specimen ID, the UUID for an ECG waveform or a medical image.

Notes: Identifier for a record that is unique within a domain for a study and that remains invariant through subsequent versions of the dataset, even if the content of the record is modified. When a record is deleted, this value must not be reused to identify another record in either the current or future versions of the domain.

Definition: A sponsor-defined sequence of characters used to identify an instance of an observation.
Examples: A preprinted line identifier on a Concomitant Medications form.

Definition: A sequence of characters used to uniquely identify a record, for a subject, in one domain and link it to 1 or more records for that subject in another domain.
Notes: This may be a one-to-one or a one-to-many relationship.
Examples: A value that links a single tumor to multiple measurements/assessments performed at different times.

Definition: A sequence of characters used to uniquely identify a group of records, for a subject, in one domain and link it to 1 or more records for that subject in another domain.
Notes: This will usually be a many-to-one relationship.
Examples: A value that links multiple tumor measurement/assessments to a single response to therapy.

Notes: A sequence number that identifies the beat within an ECG.

Definition: An assigned numeric identifier that aligns to the chronological order of a clinical encounter.
Notes: Numeric version of VISIT, used for sorting. VISITNUM does not have to be an integer value.

Definition: The label for a protocol-defined clinical encounter.
The planned study day of a clinical encounter relative to the sponsor-defined reference start date.
Notes: Should be an integer.

Variable Label: Planned Order of Element Within Arm
Definition: An assigned numeric identifier that gives the planned order of the element within the trial arm of the study.
Notes: See Section 5.1.1.2, Trial Arms.

Definition: A time period defined in the protocol with a study-specific purpose.
Notes: The epoch associated with an observation is determined by the start date or start date and time of the observation, or the date/time of collection if start date/time is not collected (see Section 5.1.1.2, Trial Arms).

Reproductive phase with which the reproductive stage of the reproductive path is associated. Defined in Trial Paths domain. The RPHASE variable is Required when any Reproductive Phase Day variable is used.

Variable Label: Planned Repro Phase Day of Observation
Definition: The day within the reproductive phase on which the test or observation was scheduled to occur.
Notes: Expressed as an integer.

Variable Label: Planned Repro Phase Day of Obs Start
Definition: The day within the reproductive phase on which the test or observation was scheduled to begin.
Notes: Expressed as an integer.

Variable Label: Planned Repro Phase Day of Obs End
Definition: The day within the reproductive phase on which the test or observation was scheduled to end.
Notes: Expressed as an integer.

Definition: The date or date and time of the assessment or the specimen or data collection from the subject, represented in a standardized character format.
The start date or date and time of an intervention or event, represented in a standardized character format.
Notes: The start date of a Findings class record is stored in the --DTC variable.

Definition: The end date or date and time of an intervention, event, or finding, represented in a standardized character format.
The number of days from the sponsor-defined reference start date to the date of collection (--DTC), used in study data tabulation.
Notes: The sponsor-defined reference start date is RFSTDTC in Demographics.

Variable Label: Study Day of Start of Observation
Definition: The number of days from the sponsor-defined reference start date to the start of an intervention or event (--STDTC), used for study data tabulation.
Notes: The sponsor-defined reference start date is RFSTDTC in Demographics.

Variable Label: Study Day of End of Observation
Definition: The number of days from the sponsor-defined reference start date to the end of an intervention, event, or finding (--ENDTC), used for study data tabulation.
Notes: The sponsor-defined reference start date is RFSTDTC in Demographics.

Definition: The nominal study day, relative to the sponsor-defined reference start date, used by data collection and reporting systems for grouping records for observations that may be scheduled to occur on different days into a single study day (e.g., for output on a tabulation report).
The name for a protocol-defined nominal study day.
Notes: As presented in the study report.

Variable Label: Actual Repro Phase Day of Observation
Definition: The day within the reproductive phase on which the test or observation occurred.
Notes: Expressed as an integer.

Variable Label: Actual Repro Phase Day of Obs Start
Definition: The day within the reproductive phase on which the test or observation began.
Notes: Expressed as an integer.

Variable Label: Actual Repro Phase Day of Obs End
Definition: The day within the reproductive phase on which the test or observation ended.
Notes: Expressed as an integer.

Variable Label: Day of Obs Relative to Exposure
Notes: The actual study day of an intervention, event, or finding, derived relative to the first exposure to any protocol-specified treatment. Expressed in integer days relative to RFXSTDTC in Demographics.

Variable Label: Start Day of Obs Relative to Exposure
Notes: The actual study day of the start of an intervention or event, derived relative to the first exposure to any protocol-specified treatment. Expressed in integer days relative to RFXSTDTC in Demographics.

Variable Label: End Day of Obs Relative to Exposure
Notes: The actual study day of the end of an intervention, event, or finding, derived relative to the first exposure to any protocol-specified treatment. Expressed in integer days relative to RFXSTDTC in Demographics.

Variable Label: Day of Obs Rel to Challenge Agent
Notes: The actual study day of an intervention, event, or finding, derived relative to the first exposure to the challenge agent that induces the disease or condition that the investigational treatment is intended to cure, mitigate, treat, or prevent. Expressed in integer days relative to RFCSTDTC in Demographics.

Variable Label: Start Day of Obs Rel to Challenge Agent
Notes: The actual study day of the start of an intervention or event derived relative to the first exposure to the challenge agent that induces the disease or condition that the investigational treatment is intended to c ure, mitigate, treat, or prevent. Expressed in integer days relative to RFCSTDTC in Demographics.

Variable Label: End Day of Obs Rel to Challenge Agent
Notes: The actual study day of the end of an intervention, event, or finding derived relative to the first exposure to the challenge agent that induces the disease or condition that the investigational treatment is intended to cure, mitigate, treat, or prevent. Expressed in integer days relative to RFCSTDTC in Demographics.

Definition: The collected length of time during which an observation continues, represented in a standardized character format.
Notes: Used only if collected on the CRF and not derived.

Definition: The description of the time when a protocol-defined activity is planned to occur, used for study data tabulation.
Notes: This may be represented as an elapsed time relative to a fixed reference point (e.g., time since last dose). See --TPTNUM and --TPTREF.

Definition: The numeric identifier of when an observation is planned to occur.
Notes: Used in sorting.

Variable Label: Planned Elapsed Time from Time Point Ref
Definition: The interval of time between a planned time point and a fixed reference point, represented in a standardized character format.
Notes: The fixed reference point is in --TPTREF. This variable is useful where there are repetitive measures. Not a clock time or a date/time variable, but an interval.

Definition: The description of a time point that acts as a fixed reference for a series of planned time points, used for study data tabulation.
Notes: Description of the fixed reference point referred to by --ELTM, --TPTNUM, --TPT, --STINT, and --ENINT.

Definition: The actual date or date and time of a time point that acts as a fixed reference for a series of planned time points, represented in a standardized character format.
Notes: The fixed reference point is in --TPTREF.

Definition: The characterization of the start of an observation relative to the study reference period.
Notes: The sponsor-defined reference period is a continuous period of time defined by a discrete starting point and a discrete ending point represented by RFSTDTC and RFENDTC in Demographics.

Definition: The characterization of the end of an observation relative to the study reference period.
Notes: The sponsor-defined reference period is a continuous period of time defined by a discrete starting point and a discrete ending point represented by RFSTDTC and RFENDTC in Demographics.

Definition: The planned time interval for which an observation is assessed, represented in a standardized character format.
Notes: Usually used with --DTC to describe an interval of this duration that ended at the time represented in --DTC.
Examples: -P2M to represent a period of the past 2 months as the evaluation interval for a question from a questionnaire.

Definition: A textual description of the planned time interval for which an observation is assessed, where the interval is not able to be represented in a standardized character format.
Notes: A value that cannot be represented in ISO 8601 format.

Variable Label: Start Relative to Reference Time Point
Definition: The characterization of the start of an observation relative to a reference time point.
Notes: The sponsor-defined reference time point is in --STTPT.

Definition: The description or date and/or time of a time point that acts as a fixed reference for characterizing the start of an observation.
Notes: This is the sponsor-defined reference point referred to by --STRTPT.

Variable Label: End Relative to Reference Time Point
Definition: The characterization of the end of an observation relative to a reference time point.
Notes: The sponsor-defined reference time point is in --ENTPT.

Definition: The description or date and/or time of a time point that acts as a fixed reference for characterizing the end of an observation.
Notes: This is the sponsor-defined reference point referred to by --ENRTPT.

The name of a specific instance of a Disease Milestone Type (MIDSTYPE) described in the Trial Disease Milestones dataset (see Section 5.1.4.3, Trial Disease Milestones). This should be unique within a subject. Used only in conjunction with RELMIDS and MIDSDTC.
The temporal relationship of the observation to the Disease Milestone Instance Name in MIDS.
The start date/time of the Disease Milestone Instance Name in MIDS.

Definition: The start of a planned assessment interval relative to a reference time point, represented in a standardized character format.
Notes: The reference time point is in --TPTREF. As this variable describes planned timing of an assessment, caution should be exercised when using outside of the Findings class of domains. In an Events or Interventions domain, it may refer to the interval over which --OCCUR is assessed.

Definition: The end of a planned assessment interval relative to a reference time point, represented in a standardized character format.
Notes: The reference time point is in --TPTREF. As this variable describes planned timing of an assessment, caution should be exercised when using outside of the Findings class of domains. In an Events or Interventions domain, it may refer to the interval over which --OCCUR is assessed.

Definition: The number of days from the start of dosing to the earliest detection of a condition or pathogen.

Usage Restrictions: Only in Findings class specimen-based domains: BS, CP, GF, IS, LB, MB, MS, MI, PC, PP
Notes: An indication that the specimen was collected at a single point in time. The value is "Y" or null.

Usage Restrictions: Only in Findings class specimen-based domains: BS, CP, GF, IS, LB, MB, MS, MI, PC, PP
Notes: Planned duration of a finding. For a sample-based finding, this could apply to the planned duration of specimen collection.

Definition: The reported name of the drug, procedure, or therapy.
Notes: The topic for the intervention observation, usually the verbatim name of the treatment, drug, medicine, or therapy given during the dosing interval for the observation.

Definition: A value which represents an alteration to a collected value for coding purposes.
Notes: If the value for --TRT is modified for coding purposes, then the modified text is placed here.

Definition: Standardized or dictionary-derived text for the description of an event or intervention.
Notes: Equivalent to the generic drug name in WHODrug, or a term in SNOMED, ICD-9, or other published or sponsor-defined dictionaries.

Definition: The state that may be applied to a record to indicate its phase in a life cycle or business process (e.g., scheduled, performed).
A grouping or classification of the topic of the finding, event, or intervention.
A further grouping or classification of the category for the topic of the finding, event, or intervention.
Notes: The category is in --CAT.

Definition: An indication that the event or intervention was prospectively stated or detailed on the CRF.
Notes: Values should be "Y" or null.

Definition: An indication as to whether a prespecified event or intervention has occurred.

Notes: --REASOC is the reason the intervention did or did not occur, according to the value in --OCCUR. This does not replace --INDC.
Used to indicate when a question about the occurrence of a prespecified intervention was not answered. Should be null or have a value of "NOT DONE".

Definition: The explanation for why requested information was not available.
Notes: Used in conjunction with --STAT when value is "NOT DONE".
The way in which the event, visit, or contact was conducted.
Indicates whether the intervention was changed due to an epidemic or pandemic.

Definition: The sign, symptom, or condition that is the basis for initiation of a treatment.
A standardized or dictionary-derived name for a grouping of drugs, procedures, or therapies.
A standardized or dictionary-derived short sequence of characters used to represent a grouping of drugs, procedures, or therapies.
Notes: Used to represent code for --CLAS.

Definition: The quantity of an agent (e.g., drug, substance, radiation) taken or absorbed at a single administration.
Notes: Not populated when --DOSTXT is populated.

Definition: A textual description of the quantity of an agent (e.g., drug, substance, radiation) taken or absorbed at a single administration.
Notes: Not populated when --DOSE is populated.

Definition: The unit of measure for the administered agent (e.g., drug, substance, radiation), using standardized values.
Notes: Units for --DOSE, --DOSTOT, or --DOSTXT.
A description of a statistically derived estimate of a dose with a certain toxicological or physiological effect in a population, based on data from a dose-response study.
The quantity given for the multiplier of --TDOSD.
Examples: If --TDOSD="LD50" and --FTDOSD="5", then the value represented by --DOSE and --DOSU is 5 times the LD50.

Definition: Physical characteristics of a drug product, (e.g., tablet, capsule, or solution) that contains a drug substance, generally (but not necessarily) in association with one or more other ingredients.
The number of times that an agent (e.g., drug, substance, radiation) is administered per unit of time.
The quantity of an agent (e.g., drug, substance, radiation) taken or absorbed on a single day.
Notes: Uses the units in --DOSU.

Definition: The planned schedule for the administration of an agent (e.g., drug, substance, radiation).
Designation of the part of the body through which or into which, or the way in which, a substance is introduced.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or distributor to a specific quantity of manufactured material or product.
Notes: Although the identifier for a lot is generally called a lot number, it may contain characters other than digits (e.g., letters).
Anatomical location of an intervention, such as an injection site.

Usage Restrictions: Not in human clinical trials; EX domain only
Definition: Method of administration of the treatment.

Notes: Qualifier for anatomical location further detailing laterality of intervention administration.
Qualifier for anatomical location further detailing directionality of intervention administration.
Qualifier for anatomical location further detailing the distribution, which means arrangement of or apportioning of the intervention administration.

Definition: An indication as to whether a subject has abstained from food and liquid for a prescribed amount of time.
Notes: Valid values include "Y", "N", "U", or null if not relevant.

Definition: The amount of active ingredient per unit of pharmaceutical dosage form.
The unit of measure for the amount of active ingredient per unit of pharmaceutical dosage form, using standardized values.
Notes: Unit for --PSTRG.

Definition: A carrier or inert medium in which a medicinally active agent is administered.
Amount of the prepared product (treatment plus vehicle) administered.
Notes: Note: Should not be diluent amount alone.

Definition: The unit of measure for the prepared product (treatment plus vehicle) using standardized values.
The explanation given for why a dose was changed as compared to a previous dose.

Notes: Reason the treatment was discontinued.

Definition: An indication that the performed test or observation was done at a time that was not planned.
Notes: If a test or observation was performed based upon a schedule defined in the protocol, this flag should be null. Expected values are "Y" or null. This variable would not be needed when information on planned assessments is provided, such as when the Trial Visits (TV) and Subject Visits (SV) domains are used.
An indicator as to whether the animal subject was restrained during the intervention period. Expected values are "Y" or null.
A description of whether the restraint was physical and/or chemical.

Definition: The collected name for an event observation.
Notes: The verbatim or prespecified name of the event.

Definition: A value which represents an alteration to a collected value for coding.
Notes: If the value for --TERM is modified for coding purposes, then the modified text is placed here.

Definition: The lowest-level term assigned to the event from MedDRA.
The lowest-level term code assigned to the event from MedDRA.
Standardized or dictionary-derived text for the description of an event or intervention.
Notes: Equivalent to the Preferred Term ("PT" in MedDRA).
Specifies the aspect of the medical condition or event by which MHSTDTC and/or the MHENDTC is defined.

Definition: The preferred term code assigned to the event from the MedDRA dictionary.
The high-level term from the primary hierarchy assigned to the event from MedDRA.
The high-level term code from the primary hierarchy assigned to the event from MedDRA.
The high-level group term from the primary hierarchy assigned to the event from MedDRA.
The high-level group term code from the primary hierarchy assigned to the event from MedDRA.
A grouping or classification of the topic of the finding, event, or intervention.
A further grouping or classification of the category for the topic of the finding, event, or intervention.
Notes: The category is in --CAT.

Definition: An indication that the event or intervention was prospectively stated or detailed on the CRF.
Notes: Value is "Y" for prespecified events, null for spontaneously reported events.

Definition: An indication as to whether a prespecified event or intervention has occurred.

Notes: --REASOC is the reason the event did or did not occur, according to the value in --OCCUR.
Used to indicate when a question about the occurrence of a prespecified event was not answered. Should be null or have a value of "NOT DONE".

Definition: The explanation for why requested information was not available.
Notes: Used in conjunction with --STAT when its value is "NOT DONE".

Definition: A standardized or dictionary-derived name for the body system or organ class.
Notes: Body system or system organ class assigned for analysis from a standard hierarchy (e.g., MedDRA) associated with an event.

Variable Label: Body System or Organ Class Code
Definition: A standardized or dictionary-derived short sequence of characters used to represent the body system or organ class.
Notes: MedDRA System Organ Class code corresponding to --BODSYS assigned for analysis.

Definition: The system organ class from the primary hierarchy assigned in the MedDRA dictionary.
The system organ class code from the primary hierarchy assigned in the MedDRA dictionary.

Notes: The way in which the event, visit, or contact was conducted.
Indicates whether the event was changed due to an epidemic or pandemic. Not the same as whether a medical condition was caused by an epidemic or pandemic.
Describes anatomical location relevant for the event.
Qualifier for anatomical location, further detailing laterality.
Qualifier for anatomical location, further detailing directionality.
Qualifier for anatomical location, further detailing the distribution (i.e., arrangement of, apportioning of).

Definition: The role of the individual or entity responsible for the receipt of the transferred object (e.g., device, specimen).
Notes: The party could be an individual (e.g., subject), an organization (e.g., sponsor), or a location that is a proxy for an individual or organization (e.g., site). It is usually a somewhat general term that is further identified in the --PRTYID variable.

Definition: A sequence of characters used to uniquely identify the individual or entity responsible for the receipt of the transferred object (e.g., device, specimen).
Notes: Used in conjunction with --PARTY.

Definition: The quality or degree of harm associated with a finding or event, as collected.
A collected indication as to whether an event meets regulatory criteria for seriousness.
Notes: Valid values are "Y" and "N".

Definition: An action taken with study treatment as the result of the event.
An action taken unrelated to study treatment, as the result of the event.
An action taken with a device as the result of the event.
Notes: The device may or may not be the device under study.

Definition: The investigator's assessment of the likelihood that the study treatment was the cause of the event.
A judgement as to the likelihood that the device caused the event.
Notes: The device may or may not be the device under study. Controlled terminology from EC Directive MEDDEV 2.7/3 March 2015 is required in EU but not US.

Definition: The investigator's assessment of the causal relationship of the event to a non-study treatment.
Examples: MORE LIKELY RELATED TO ASPIRIN USE

Definition: A characterization of the temporal pattern of occurrences of the event.
The status associated with the result or conclusion of the event.
An indication as to whether the reason an event was serious was because the event was associated with cancer.
Notes: Valid values are "Y", "N", and null.

Definition: An indication as to whether the reason an event is serious is because the event is associated with congenital anomaly or birth defect in an offspring of the subject.
Notes: Valid values are "Y", "N", and null.

Definition: An indication as to whether the reason an event is serious is because the event resulted in a significant, persistent, or permanent change, impairment, damage, or disruption in the subject's body function/structure, physical activities, and/or quality of life.
Notes: Valid values are "Y", "N", and null.

Definition: An indication as to whether the reason an event is serious is because the event resulted in death.
Notes: Valid values are "Y", "N", and null.

Definition: An indication as to whether the reason an event is serious is because the event resulted in or prolonged hospitalization.
Notes: Valid values are "Y", "N", and null.

Definition: An indication as to whether the reason an event is serious is because the event resulted in a substantial risk of dying.
Notes: Valid values are "Y", "N", and null.

Definition: An indication as to whether the reason an event is serious is because the event is associated with overdose.
Notes: Valid values are "Y", "N", and null.

Definition: An indication as to whether the reason an event is serious is because the event may jeopardize the subject and may require intervention to prevent one of the other outcomes associated with serious adverse events.
Notes: Valid values are "Y", "N", and null.

Valid values are "Y", "N", and null. Expected use is in medical device-related trials. It is part of the definition of a serious AE as represented in 21 CFR Part 803.3(w)(3). \n Records whether medical or surgical intervention was necessary to preclude permanent impairment of a body function, or prevent permanent damage to a body structure, with either situation suspected to be due to the use of a medical product.

The assessment is about a device identified in the data (i.e., which has an SPDEVID). The device may be ancillary or under study. \n Any serious adverse effect on health or safety or any life-threatening problem or death caused by or associated with a device, if that effect, problem, or death was not previously identified in nature, severity, or degree of incidence in the investigational plan or application (including a supplementary plan or application), or any other unanticipated serious problem associated with a device that relates to the rights, safety, or welfare of subjects. (21 CFR 812.3(s)).

Variable Label: Rel of AE to Device-Related Procedure
Notes: The investigator's opinion as to the likelihood that the device-related study procedure caused the AE (e.g., implant/insertion, revision/adjustment, explant/removal) \n The relationship is to a device-related procedure where the device is identified in the data (i.e., which has an SPDEVID). The device may be ancillary or under study.

Variable Label: Rel of AE to Non-Dev-Rel Study Activity
Notes: The investigator's opinion as to the causality of the event as related to other protocol-required activities, actions or assessments (e.g., medication changes, tests/assessments, other procedures). \n The relationship is to a protocol-specified non-device-related activity where the device is identified in the data (i.e., which has an SPDEVID). The device may be ancillary or under study.

Definition: An indication as to whether a non-study treatment was given because of the occurrence of the event.
Notes: Valid values are "Y", "N", and null.

Definition: The standardized or dictionary-derived name for an untoward event or finding.
Notes: Sponsor should specify which scale and version is used in the Sponsor Comments column of the Define-XML document.

Definition: A categorical classification of the severity of an event or finding, based on a standard scale, used in study data tabulation.
Notes: Sponsor should specify which scale and version is used in the Sponsor Comments column of the Define-XML document.
Examples: A toxicity grade from the NCI CTCAE.

Definition: An indication that the performed test or observation was done at a time that was not planned.
Notes: If a test or observation was performed based upon a schedule defined in the protocol, this flag should be null. Expected values are "Y" or null. This variable would not be needed when information on planned assessments is provided, such as when the Trial Visits (TV) and Subject Visits (SV) domains are used.

Variable Label: Short Name of Measurement, Test, or Exam
Definition: The standardized or dictionary-derived short sequence of characters used to represent the measurement, test, or examination.
Notes: Used as a column name when converting a dataset from a vertical format to a horizontal format. The short value can be up to 8 characters.

Variable Label: Name of Measurement, Test, or Exam
Definition: The standardized or dictionary-derived name of the measurement, test, or examination.

Notes: Used to further subset the cell population identified in CPTEST based on the use of additional marker(s) that define a sublineage. The value in CPSBMRKS is used in combination with values in CPTEST and CPCELSTA to fully describe the cell population being measured. As such, it is an essential component of the full test name.
Examples: Three unnamed sublineages of monocytes have been identified: CCR2+CD16-; CCR2-CD16+; and CCR2+CD16+. Whereas the entire monocyte cell population can be defined as CD14+ cells, the additional CCR2 and CD16 markers are used to differentiate one sublineage from another, none of which has yet been given a name by the scientific community. By combining the CPTEST value of "Monocyte Subset" with the value of "CCR2+CD16-" in CPSBMRKS, the full test is defined to be the CCR2+CD16- monocyte subpopulation.

Notes: A textual description of a subset of the cell population identified in CPTEST based on a particular functional and/or biological state (e.g., primed, activated, proliferating, senescent, G2-arrested). When populated, the values in CPCELSTA and CPSMRKS, in combination with values in CPTEST and CPSBMRKS, fully describe the cell population being measured.
Identifies the marker(s) or indicator(s) used to define the cell state (i.e., the value in CPCELSTA).
Examples: When Ki67 expression is used to determine that a cell population is in a proliferating state (i.e., CPCELSTA value = "PROLIFERATING"), the value "Ki67+" in CPCSMRKS indicates that positive expression of Ki67 was used to define the population as proliferating. Similarly, a value of "Ki67-" in CPCSMRKS would indicate that lack of expression of Ki67 defined the "NON-PROLIFERATING" cell state in CPCELSTA. The CPCSMRKS value is useful for quickly determining which marker(s) were used to classify (i.e., operationally define) a cell population based on a functional/biological state.

Notes: The way in which the measurement, test, or examination was conducted.
Indicates whether the measurement, test, or examination was changed due to an epidemic or pandemic.

Usage Restrictions: CP, IS, and LB domains only
Notes: Identifies any planned condition imposed by the assay system on the specimen at the time the test is performed.
Examples: Stimulating or activating agents, assay temperature, incubation time \n "STIMULATED", "NON-STIMULATED", "25 C", "37 C".

Usage Restrictions: CP, IS, and LB domains only
Notes: The textual description of the agent used to impose a test condition identified in CPTSTCND. For example, records might be produced for the same test run under stimulating (CPTSTCND value = "STIMULATED") conditions produced by different stimulating agents.
Examples: "Phorbol myristate acetate", "Concanavalin A, PHA-P", "TNF-alpha, Ionomycin", "Candida antigen"

Usage Restrictions: CP, IS, and LB domains only
Notes: The textual description of the agent that's binding to the entity in the --TEST variable. The --BDAGNT variable is used to indicate that there is a binding relationship between the entities in the --TEST and --BDAGNT variables, regardless of direction.--BDAGNT is not a method qualifier. It should only be used when the actual interest of the measurement is the binding interaction between the two entities in --TEST and --BDAGNT. In other words, the combination of --TEST and --BDAGNT should describe the thing, the entity, or the analyte being measured, without the need for additional variables. \n The binding agent may be, but is not limited to, a test article, a portion of the test article, a related compound, an endogenous molecule, an allergen, or an infectious agent.
Identifies the antibody clone (e.g., supplier-provided catalog name) used to confer specificity for the binding agent specified in CPBDAGNT.

The text string identifying the full set of markers/indicators used by the laboratory to operationally define the complete test. Because laboratories often use different markers/indicators to identify a cell population, the relationship between a named cell population in CPTEST (as combined with CPSBMRKS and CPCELSTA values) and the set of markers used to identify that population is many-to-one. To ensure nuances important for accurately interpreting the data are accounted for and which arise from the use of different sets of markers, it is necessary to operationally define the test in terms of the markers/indicators used to perform that test.

The sponsor-defined name assigned to a gate. Gates are electronic (device setting or software-defined) boundaries set by a user to virtually parse a specimen into discrete populations based on a set of defined characteristics (e.g., presence, absence, or intensity of expression of various markers; physical size; internal complexity or granularity). Gates are used to constrain data collection or analysis to a specific cell population or region of interest within the specimen.

The text string identifying the set of parameters and the order in which they are applied to define the gating strategy. In practice, a series of 2-dimensional subgates based on 2 different cell characteristics (i.e., markers/indicators/physical properties) are most often combined until the cell population of interest is sufficiently resolved (i.e., electronically isolated) from other cell populations contained within the specimen. \n For complex analyses, differences in gating strategies can produce subtle differences in results obtained for a test. To ensure nuances important for accurately interpreting the data are accounted for and which arise from the use of different gating strategies, it is often necessary to qualify the test in terms of the gating strategy. For some purposes, however, and at the discretion of the sponsor, only the ultimate or penultimate gate is identified. When specifying the gating strategy in CPGATDEF, each subgate should be listed in the order it was applied and separated from the next sub-gate using the vertical line or pipe character ("|").
The textual description of the high-level purpose of the test at the operational level.

The textual description of the entity secreted by the cells represented in --TEST. The combination of --TEST and --MSBCE should describe the thing, the entity, or the analyte being measured, without the need for additional variables.

The name of the drug or other material for which resistance is tested. The agent may be used for in vitro testing or may be used in tests for genetic markers or in direct phenotypic drug-sensitivity testing.

The amount of drug or other material listed in MSAGENT per unit volume or weight. Used when the agent is part of the prespecified test. Not to be used when the concentration is a result of a test such as minimal inhibitory concentration, IC50, or EC50.
Unit of measure for MSCONC.

Definition: A value which represents an alteration to a collected value for coding purposes.

Notes: Further description of --TESTCD and --TEST.
Examples: STAINING INTENSITY when MITEST="Human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 2"

Notes: Sponsor's description of a test. This variable is particularly valuable for identifying the cell population on which certain tests are conducted when it is not identified in the Test Name (CPTEST; e.g., tests for quantitative expression of a particular marker).

Definition: A grouping or classification of the topic of the finding, event, or intervention.
A further grouping or classification of the category for the topic of the finding, event, or intervention.
Notes: The category is in --CAT.
Sponsor-defined textual description used to group tests run together as part of a test panel. Can be used with --GRPID to ensure that relationships between associated tests are accurately identified.

Definition: The particular way that a subject's body is placed or situated during an assessment.
A standardized or dictionary-derived name for the body system or organ class.

Variable Label: Result or Finding in Original Units
Definition: The result of the measurement, test, or examination, as originally received or collected.
The unit of measure for the result (as originally received or collected) of the measurement, test, or examination.
Notes: Unit for --ORRES and --ORREF.
Classifies the scale of the original result value with respect to whether the result is, for example, ordinal, nominal, quantitative, or narrative.
Classifies the kind of result (i.e., property type) originally reported for the test.

Used to indicate the type of a collected summary result. This is used for summary results collected on a CRF or provided by an external vendor (e.g., central lab). \n If the summary result is derived by the sponsor using individual source data records, the summary result is represented in ADaM. If a sponsor has both a collected or vendor-provided summary result and a derived summary result, the collected or vendor-provided summary result is represented in SDTM and the derived summary result is represented in ADaM.

Definition: The lowest value in a normal or reference range for the result (as originally received or collected) of the measurement, test, or examination.
The highest value in a normal or reference range for the result (as originally received or collected) of the measurement, test, or examination.

Notes: Reference value for the result or finding as originally received or collected. --ORREF uses the same units as --ORRES, if applicable.
Examples: Value from predicted normal value in spirometry tests.

Notes: The lowest threshold (as originally received or collected) for reliably detecting the presence or absence of substance measured by a specific test. The value for the field will be as described in documentation from the instrument or lab vendor.

Variable Label: Result or Finding in Standard Format
Definition: The standardized result of the measurement, test, or examination, in character format.
Notes: --STRESC should store all results or findings in character format; if results are numeric, they should also be stored in numeric format in --STRESN.
Examples: If various tests have results "NONE", "NEG", and "NEGATIVE" in --ORRES and these results effectively have the same meaning, they could be represented in standard format in --STRESC as "NEGATIVE".

Usage Restrictions: Not in human clinical trials; IC Domain only
Notes: Label or identifier that describes the location or position of a fetal implantation site in the uterus (or uterine horn) when classifying implantations during a uterine examination in a reproductive toxicology study.

Definition: The standardized result of the measurement, test, or examination in numeric format.
Notes: Copied in numeric format from --STRESC. --STRESN should store all numeric test results or findings.

Definition: The unit of measure for the standardized result of the measurement, test, or examination.
The lowest value in a normal or reference range for the standardized result of the measurement, test, or examination.
The highest value in a normal or reference range for the standardized result of the measurement, test, or examination.
A set of normal or reference values for the standardized character result, in an ordinal scale or categorical grouping.

Notes: Reference value for the result or finding copied or derived from --ORREF in a standard format.

Variable Label: Numeric Reference Result in Std Units
Notes: Reference value for continuous or numeric results or findings in standard format or in standard units. --STREFN uses the same units as --STRESN, if applicable.

Definition: A classification of the original or standardized result as it relates to a normal or reference result range.
Notes: May be defined by --ORNRLO and --ORNRHI or other objective criteria.

Definition: A grouping or classification of the results of an assessment.
Notes: The result is in --STRESC.
Identifies whether the variation can be passed to the next generation.
An identifier for the genome reference used to generate the reported result.
Examples: For example, Genome Reference Consortium Human Build 38 patch release 13 may be represented as GRCh38.p13.

Notes: The designation (name or number) of the chromosome or contig on which the variant or other feature appears.
A published symbol for the portion of the genome serving as a locus for the experiment/test.
A description of the type of genomic entity that is represented by the published symbol in --SYM.
Specifies the location within a sequence for the observed value in --ORRES.
The portion of the locus in which the variation was found.
A unique identifier for the sequence used as the reference to identify the genetic variation in the result.
A unique identifier for the variation that has been publicly characterized in an external database.
An arbitrary identifier used to differentiate between copies of a genetic target of interest present on homologous chromosomes.
Characterization of the duration of a biological process resulting in a particular finding.
Description of the distribution pattern of a finding within the examined area.

Definition: Anatomical location where the result was observed.
Notes: Location where the result was observed (as opposed to the location specified for examination). This location may have a higher degree of specificity than the location specified for examination.
Examples: "PINNA" when --LOC is "EAR" \n "LUNG, LEFT LOWER LOBE" where --LOC is "CHEST" \n "CORTEX" when --SPEC is "KIDNEY"

Notes: Used to indicate that a question was not asked or a test was not done, or a test was attempted but did not generate a result. Should be null or have a value of "NOT DONE".

Definition: The explanation for why requested information was not available.
Notes: Used in conjunction with --STAT when value is "NOT DONE".

Definition: The filename and/or path to external data not stored in the same format and possibly not the same location as the other data for a study.
Examples: A filename and/or path for an ECG waveform or a medical image.

Definition: The name of the vendor performing an assessment.
A short sequence of characters used to represent laboratory and clinical tests within the Logical Observation Identifiers Names and Codes (LOINC) database.
The type of sample material taken from a biological entity.
The specific anatomical or biological region of a tissue or organ specimen.
Notes: As defined in the protocol.
Examples: A section or part of what is described in the --SPEC variable \n "CORTEX", "MEDULLA", "MUCOSA"

Definition: The physical state or quality of a sample for assessment.
An indication as to whether a sample is suitable for testing.
Notes: The value will be "N" if the specimen is not usable, and null if the specimen is usable.
Anatomical location of the subject relevant to the collection of the measurement.
Qualifier for anatomical location or specimen further detailing laterality.
Qualifier for anatomical location or specimen further detailing directionality.
Qualifier for anatomical location or specimen further detailing the distribution (i.e., arrangement or apportioning of).
Method of the test or examination.

Definition: A sequence of characters used to uniquely identify a particular run of a test on a particular batch of samples.

Notes: Analysis method applied to obtain a summarized result. Analysis method describes the method of secondary processing applied to a complex observation result (e.g., an image, a genetic sequence).
The sensitivity of the test methodology with respect to observation, detection, or quantification.

Definition: An electrical recording from some region of the body that represents the voltage difference between 2 electrodes.
The subject's level of consciousness.

Notes: Operationally derived indicator used to identify the last non-missing value prior to RFXSTDTC. Result value is in --STRESC. Should be "Y" or null.

Definition: An indication that the record is the sponsor-defined baseline assessment, used in study data tabulation.
Notes: Result value is in --STRESC. Should be "Y" or null.

Definition: An indication as to whether a subject has abstained from food and liquid for a prescribed amount of time.
Notes: Valid values include "Y", "N", "U", or null if not relevant.

Definition: An indication that the measurement or finding is not a collected value but is processed or computed by the sponsor from collected data.
Notes: Should be "Y" or null.
Examples: The average of other records used as a computed baseline.

Usage Restrictions: Not in QS, FT, and clinical classifications use case of RS
Definition: The role of the person(s) providing an evaluation, appraisal, or interpretation.
Notes: Used only for results that are subjective (e.g., assigned by a person or a group).

Usage Restrictions: Not in QS, FT, and clinical classifications use case of RS
Definition: A sequence of characters used to uniquely identify the evaluator(s).
Notes: Used to distinguish multiple evaluators with the same role recorded in --EVAL.

Definition: An indication that a record is the endorsed assessment.
Notes: Expected values can include "Y", "N", or null. This is not intended to be an analysis flag to indicate acceptability for a given analysis.

Definition: The standardized or dictionary-derived name for an untoward event or finding.
Notes: Sponsors should specify which scale and version is used in the Sponsor Comments column of the Define-XML document.

Definition: A categorical classification of the severity of an event or finding, based on a standard scale, used in study data tabulation.
Notes: Sponsors should specify which scale and version is used in the Sponsor Comments column of the Define-XML document.
Examples: A grade from the NCI CTCAE. \n "2"

Definition: The quality or degree of harm associated with a finding or event, as collected.
An indication as to whether an observation is clinically significant based on judgment.
Notes: For collected assessments of clinical significance of a result.

Definition: An indication that a particular finding is related to the cause of death.
The lowest threshold for reliably quantifying the amount of substance measured by a specific test, in standardized units.
Notes: Units will be those used for --STRESU.

Definition: The highest threshold for reliably detecting the result of a specific test in standardized units.
Notes: Units will be those used for --STRESU.

Definition: The explanation for why a test, measurement, or assessment is executed.
An indication that the result is to be excluded from all calculations.
Notes: Expected to be "Y" or null. --EXCLFL should be null when --STAT is "NOT DONE".

Definition: The explanation for why a result is excluded from all calculations.
Notes: Used in conjunction with --EXCLFL when its value is "Y".

Definition: An indication that the performed test or observation was done at a time that was not planned.
Notes: If a test or observation was performed based upon a schedule defined in the protocol, this flag should be null. Expected values are "Y" or null. This variable would not be needed when information on planned assessments is provided, such as when the Trial Visits (TV) and Subject Visits (SV) domains are used.
The instance number of a test that is repeated within a given timeframe for the same test. The level of granularity can vary (e.g., within a time point or within a visit).
Examples: Multiple measurements of blood pressure or multiple analyses of a sample.

Notes: An indicator as to whether the animal was restrained during the observation period. Expected values are "Y" or null.
A description of whether the restraint was physical and/or chemical.
Used in domains modeled as Findings About Events or Findings About Interventions. Describes the event or intervention whose property is being measured in --TESTCD/--TEST.
Examples: An event of vomiting which has findings, where --OBJ="VOMIT" and the volume of VOMIT is being measured where --TESTCD="VOLUME".

Notes: Identifier for a single associated person, a group of associated persons, or a pool of associated persons. If APID identifies a pool, POOLDEF records must exist for each associated person (see Section 6.3, Pool Definition Dataset, and Section 4, Associated Persons Data).

Identifier for a related subject or pool of subjects. RSUBJID may be populated with the USUBJID of the related subject or the POOLID of the related pool. \n RSUBJID will be null for data about associated persons who are related to the study but not to any study subjects.
Identifier for a related device. RDEVID will be populated with the SPDEVID of the related device.

If RSUBJID is populated, describes the relationship of the associated person(s) identified in APID to the subject or pool identified in RSUBJID. \n If RDEVID is populated, describes the relationship of the associated person(s) identified in APID to the device identified in RDEVID. \n If RSUBJID and RDEVID are null, SREL describes the relationship of the associated person(s) identified in APID to the study identified in STUDYID.

Definition: A sequence of characters used by the sponsor to uniquely identify the study.
An abbreviation for a collection of observations, with a topic-specific commonality.
Notes: 2-character abbreviation, which must be "DM".

Definition: A sequence of characters used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.

Notes: Subject identifier, which must be unique within the study. Often the ID of the subject as recorded on a CRF.

Definition: The start date or date and time of the sponsor-defined study reference period, represented in a standardized character format.
Notes: Usually equivalent to date/time when subject was first exposed to study treatment. Required for all randomized subjects; will be null for all subjects who did not meet the milestone the date requires, such as screen failures or unassigned subjects.

Definition: The end date or date and time of the sponsor-defined study reference period, represented in a standardized character format.
Notes: Usually equivalent to the date/time when a subject was determined to have ended the trial. Often equivalent to either date/time of last exposure to study treatment or date/time of last contact with the subject. Required for all randomized subjects; null for screen failures or unassigned subjects.

Definition: The start date or date and time of the first exposure to any protocol-specified treatment or therapy, represented in a standardized character format.
The end date or date and time of the last exposure to any protocol-specified treatment or therapy, represented in a standardized character format.

Variable Label: Date/Time of First Challenge Agent Admin
Notes: The start date or date and time of the first exposure to any protocol-specified challenge agent that induces the disease or condition that the investigational treatment is intended to cure, mitigate, treat, or prevent, represented in a standardized character format. \n Equal to the earliest value of AGSTDTC for the challenge agent.

Variable Label: Date/Time of Last Challenge Agent Admin
Notes: The end date or date and time of the last exposure to any protocol-specified challenge agent that induces the disease or condition that the investigational treatment is intended to cure, mitigate, treat, or prevent, represented in a standardized character format. \n Equal to the latest value of AGENDTC for the challenge agent.

Definition: The date or date and time of informed consent, represented in a standardized character format.
The date or date and time of last contact with or information about a subject in a trial, represented in a standardized character format.
Notes: Should correspond to the last known date of contact.

Definition: The date or date and time of death, represented in a standardized character format.
Notes: Should represent the date/time that is captured in the clinical-trial database.

Definition: An indication that the subject died.
Notes: A value of "Y" indicates the subject died. Should be "Y" or null. Should be populated even when the death date is unknown.

Definition: A sequence of characters used to uniquely identify the facility associated with study-specific activities.

Notes: An identifier to describe the Investigator for the study. May be used in addition to the SITEID. Not needed if SITEID is equivalent to INVID.
Name of the investigator for a site.

Definition: The date or date and time of birth, represented in a standardized character format.
A numeric representation of the elapsed time since birth at a specific point in time defined for the trial, used for study data tabulation.
Notes: May be derived as (RFSTDTC-BRTHDTC), but BRTHDTC may not be available in all cases (due to subject privacy concerns).

Definition: The age at a specific point in time defined for the trial, expressed as a range.
Notes: The age of the subject at study start, as planned, expressed as a range. If an age integer value is available, then populate the age variable instead. Either the AGE or AGETXT variable should be populated, but not both.

Definition: The unit of time used to express the age, using standardized values.

Notes: Sex of the subject.
Race of the subject. Sponsors should refer to FDA guidance regarding the collection of race data.
The ethnicity of the subject. Sponsors should refer to FDA guidance regarding the collection of ethnicity data.

Definition: The common (non-taxonomic) name for an animal used as the test system in a study.

The vendor-supplied species/strain/substrain designation for the test system under study. It may combine the species, background strain, substrain, and associated genetic modifications as supplied by the vendor (e.g. FISCHER 344, SPRAGUE-DAWLEY IGS, WISTAR Kyoto, BEAGLE, CYNOMOLGUS, RHESUS, CHIMPANZEE).

Additional clarifying details regarding the test system under study, such as a description of a phenotypic alteration associated with the specific genetic modification captured or collected in the Strain/Substrain variable.
A short sequence of characters that represents the planned arm to which the subject was assigned.
Notes: Limited to 20 characters.

Definition: The name of the planned arm to which the subject was assigned.
A short sequence of characters that represents the arm in which the subject actually participated.
Notes: Limited to 20 characters.

Definition: The name of the arm in which the subject actually participated.

Variable Label: Reason Arm and/or Actual Arm is Null
Notes: The reason why the actual arm variables are null or why both the planned and actual arm variables are null. It is assumed that if the arm and actual arm variables are null, the same reason applies to both.
A description of actual treatment for a subject who did not receive treatment described in one of the planned trial arms.

Definition: The standardized or dictionary-derived short sequence of characters used to represent the trial set.
Notes: Defined by the sponsor (see Section 5.1.2, Trial Sets). Maximum of 8 characters. This represents the code for the trial set for which parameters are being submitted.

Definition: A short sequence of characters that represents the planned reproductive path to which the subject was assigned.
Notes: Limited to 20 characters.

Definition: The country in which the investigational site is located.
The date or date and time of demographic data collection, represented in a standardized character format.
The actual study day of demographic data collection derived relative to the sponsor-defined reference start date.
Notes: The sponsor-defined reference start date is RFSTDTC.

Definition: A sequence of characters used by the sponsor to uniquely identify the study.
An abbreviation for a collection of observations, with a topic-specific commonality.
Notes: 2-character abbreviation, which must be "CO".
Domain abbreviation of the parent record(s). Null for records collected on general comments or additional information section of CRF.

Definition: A sequence of characters used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.
A sequence of characters used to uniquely identify a group of subjects that have been pooled together.
Notes: The result is not assignable to any one individual.

Definition: A sequence of characters used by the sponsor to uniquely identify a specific device.

Notes: Sequence number to ensure uniqueness within the dataset.

Identifying variable in the parent dataset that identifies the record(s) to which the comment applies (e.g., AESEQ, CMGRPID). Used only when individual comments are related to domain records. Null for comments collected on separate CRFs.
Value of identifying variable of the parent record(s). Null for comments collected on separate CRFs.
Sponsor-defined reference associated with the comment.
Examples: A CRF page number (e.g., 650), a module name (e.g., "DEMOG"), or a combination of information that identifies the reference (e.g., "650-VITALS-VISIT 2")

Notes: The text of the comment. Text over 200 characters can be added to additional columns COVAL1-COVALn.
Used to describe the originator of the comment.
Used to distinguish multiple evaluators with the same role recorded in --EVAL.
Date or date and time of comment on dedicated comment form, if collected. Should be null if this is a child record of another domain or if comment date was not collected.
Actual study day of the comment, in integer days. The algorithm for calculations must be relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC variable in the Demographics (DM) domain.

Definition: A sequence of characters used by the sponsor to uniquely identify the study.
An abbreviation for a collection of observations, with a topic-specific commonality.
Notes: 2-character abbreviation, which must be "SE".

Definition: A sequence of characters used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.

Notes: Sequence number to ensure uniqueness within the dataset. Should be assigned to be in a consistent chronological order.

ETCD (the companion to ELEMENT) is limited to 8 characters and does not have special character restrictions. These values should be short for ease of use in programming, but it is not expected that ETCD will need to serve as a variable name.
The name of the element. If ETCD has a value of "UNPLAN" then ELEMENT should be null.

Variable Label: Planned Order of Element within Arm
Definition: An assigned numeric identifier that gives the planned order of the element within the trial arm of the study.
Notes: Value for the element within the subject's assigned arm.

Definition: A time period defined in the protocol with a study-specific purpose.
Notes: Value for the element within the subject's assigned arm.
Start date or start date and time for an element for each subject.
End date/time of an element for each subject.

Variable Label: Study Day of Start of Element
Notes: Study day of start of element relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC.

Variable Label: Study Day of End of Element
Notes: Study day of end of element relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC. \n
Description of what happened to the subject during an unplanned element. Used only if ETCD has the value of "UNPLAN".

Definition: A sequence of characters used by the sponsor to uniquely identify the study.
An abbreviation for a collection of observations, with a topic-specific commonality.
Notes: 2-character abbreviation, which must be "SJ".

Definition: A sequence of characters used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.

Notes: Sequence number to ensure uniqueness within the dataset. Should be assigned to be in a consistent chronological order.
Short name of the Repro Stage used for programming and sorting. Maximum 8 characters.
The name of the Repro Stage. If RSTGCD has a value of "UNPLAN" then RSTAGE should be null.
Start date or start date and time for a Repro Stage for each subject.
End date/time for a Repro Stage for each subject.
Name of the reproductive phase with which this Repro Stage of the Repro Path is associated.
Description of what happened to the subject during an unplanned Repro Stage. Used only if RSTGCD has the value of "UNPLAN".

Definition: A sequence of characters used by the sponsor to uniquely identify the study.
An abbreviation for a collection of observations, with a topic-specific commonality.
Notes: 2-character abbreviation, which must be "SV".

Definition: A sequence of characters used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.
An assigned numeric identifier that aligns to the chronological order of a clinical encounter.
Notes: Decimal numbering may be useful for inserting unplanned visits. Used for sorting.

Definition: The label for a protocol-defined clinical encounter.
Notes: May be used in addition to VISITNUM and/or VISITDY.
An indication that the visit is planned. Values should be "Y" or null.
An indication as to whether a prespecified (planned) visit has occurred.
The reason for the value in SVOCCUR. If SVOCCUR="N", SVREASOC is the reason the visit did not occur.
The way in which the visit or contact was conducted.
Indicates whether the visit was changed due to an epidemic or pandemic.

Definition: The planned study day of a clinical encounter relative to the sponsor-defined reference start date.
Notes: The reference start date is RFSTDTC in Demographics.
Start date or start date and time for a subject's visit.
End date/time of a subject's visit.

Variable Label: Study Day of Start of Visit
Notes: Study day of start of visit relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC.

Variable Label: Study Day of End of Visit
Notes: Study day of end of visit relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC.
Description of what happened to the subject during an unplanned visit. Null for protocol-defined visits.

Definition: A sequence of characters used by the sponsor to uniquely identify the study.
An abbreviation for a collection of observations, with a topic-specific commonality.
Notes: 2-character abbreviation, which must be "SM".

Definition: A sequence of characters used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.

Notes: Sequence number given to ensure uniqueness of subject records. Should be assigned to be consistent with chronological order.
Name of the specific disease milestone. For disease milestones that can occur multiple times, the name will end with a sequence number.
The type of disease milestone.
Start date or start date and time of milestone instance (if milestone is an intervention or event), or date of milestone if the milestone is a finding.
End date/time of disease milestone Instance.

Variable Label: Study Day of Start of Milestone
Notes: Study day of start of disease milestone instance, relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC.

Variable Label: Study Day of End of Milestone
Notes: Study day of end of disease milestone instance, relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC.

Definition: A sequence of characters used by the sponsor to uniquely identify the study.
An abbreviation for a collection of observations, with a topic-specific commonality.
Notes: 2-character abbreviation, which must be "TE".

ETCD (the companion to ELEMENT) is limited to 8 characters and does not have special character restrictions. These values should be short for ease of use in programming, but it is not expected that ETCD will need to serve as a variable name.
The name of the element.
Expresses the rule for beginning the element.
Expresses the rule for ending the element. Either TEENRL or TEDUR must be present for each element.
Used when the rule for ending the element is applied after a fixed duration.

Definition: A sequence of characters used by the sponsor to uniquely identify the study.
An abbreviation for a collection of observations, with a topic-specific commonality.
Notes: 2-character abbreviation, which must be "TA".

Definition: A short sequence of characters that represents the planned arm to which the subject was assigned.
Notes: ARMCD is limited to 20 characters and does not have special character restrictions.

Definition: The name of the planned arm to which the subject was assigned.

Variable Label: Planned Order of Element within Arm
Definition: An assigned numeric identifier that gives the planned order of the element within the trial arm of the study.

Notes: ETCD (the companion to ELEMENT) is limited to 8 characters and does not have special character restrictions. These values should be short for ease of use in programming, but it is not expected that ETCD will need to serve as a variable name.
The name of the element.
Condition subjects meet, at a "branch" in the trial design at the end of this element, to be included in this arm.

If the trial design allows a subject to transition to an element other than the next element in sequence, then the conditions for transitioning to those other elements, and the alternative element sequences, are specified in this rule.

Definition: A time period defined in the protocol with a study-specific purpose.
Notes: The epoch associated with the value in ELEMENT and the value in ARMCD.

Definition: A sequence of characters used by the sponsor to uniquely identify the study.
An abbreviation for a collection of observations, with a topic-specific commonality.
Notes: 2-character abbreviation, which must be "TX".
Short name of a specific trial set, as defined by the sponsor. Maximum 8 characters. This represents the trial set for which parameters are being submitted.
Long description of a specific trial set, as defined by the sponsor.
Unique number for this record within this dataset.
Short character value for the trial set parameter described in TXPARM. Maximum 8 characters.
Term for the trial set parameter. Maximum 40 characters.
Value of the trial set parameter. Some parameters may be subject to controlled terminology.
Examples: Fed ad libitum or "Restricted Feeding" when TXPARM is "FEEDREG"

Definition: A sequence of characters used by the sponsor to uniquely identify the study.
A sequence of characters used by the sponsor to uniquely identify the study.
Notes: 2-character abbreviation, which must be "TT".
Short name of the repro stage, used for programming and sorting. Maximum 8 characters.
The name of the repro stage.

Variable Label: Rule for Start of Repro Stage
Notes: Expresses the rule for beginning the repro stage.

Variable Label: Rule for End of Repro Stage
Notes: Expresses the rule for ending the repro stage. Either TTENRL or TTDUR must be present for each repro stage.
Used when the rule for ending the repro stage is applied after a fixed duration.

Definition: A sequence of characters used by the sponsor to uniquely identify the study.
An abbreviation for a collection of observations, with a topic-specific commonality.
Notes: 2-character abbreviation, which must be "TP".

Definition: A short sequence of characters that represents the planned reproductive path to which the subject was assigned.
Notes: Limited to 20 characters. Should be populated in Demographics when repro paths have been defined in this domain.
Name of the planned repro path.

Variable Label: Order of Repro Stage within Repro Path
Notes: Number that gives the planned order of the repro stage within the repro path.

Short name of the repro stage used for programming and sorting. Maximum 8 characters. The values of RSTGCD used in the Trial Paths dataset must match values for the same repro stage in the Trial Stages dataset.
The name of the repro stage.
Conditions subjects meet, occurring at the end of a repro stage, which cause a repro path to branch off from another repro path.
Name of the reproductive phase with which this repro stage of the repro path is associated.
Sponsor protocol-defined first day of repro phase. Should be zero or 1.

Definition: A sequence of characters used by the sponsor to uniquely identify the study.
An abbreviation for a collection of observations, with a topic-specific commonality.
Notes: 2-character abbreviation, which must be "TV".

Definition: An assigned numeric identifier that aligns to the chronological order of a clinical encounter.
Notes: Numeric version of VISIT can be used for sorting.

Definition: The label for a protocol-defined clinical encounter.
Notes: May be used in addition to VISITNUM and/or VISITDY.

Definition: The planned study day of a clinical encounter relative to the sponsor-defined reference start date.
Notes: Due to its sequential nature can be used for sorting.

Definition: A short sequence of characters that represents the planned arm to which the subject was assigned.
Notes: ARMCD is limited to 20 characters and does not have special character restrictions. If the timing of visits for a trial does not depend on which Arm a subject is in, then ARMCD should be null.

Definition: The name of the planned arm to which the subject was assigned.

Notes: Rule describing when the visit starts, in relation to the sequence of elements.
Rule describing when the visit ends, in relation to the sequence of elements.

Definition: A sequence of characters used by the sponsor to uniquely identify the study.
An abbreviation for a collection of observations, with a topic-specific commonality.
Notes: 2-character abbreviation, which must be "TD".
A number given to ensure ordinal sequencing of the planned assessment schedules within a trial.

A reference to the date variable name that provides the start point from which the planned disease assessment schedule is measured. This must be referenced from the ADaM subject-level (ADSL) dataset (e.g., ANCH1DT). \n Note: TDANCVAR is to contain the name of a reference date variable name.

A fixed offset from the date provided by the variable referenced in TDANCVAR. This is used when the timing of planned cycles does not start on the exact day referenced in the variable indicated in TDANCVAR. The value of this variable will be a non-negative duration.
The planned interval between disease assessments.
The lower limit of the allowed range for the planned interval between disease assessments.
The upper limit of the allowed range for the planned interval between disease assessments.

This variable must represent the maximum number of actual assessments for the analysis that this disease assessment schedule describes. In a trial where the maximum number of assessments is not defined explicitly in the protocol (e.g., assessments occur until death), TDNUMRPT should represent the maximum number of disease assessments that support the efficacy analysis, encountered by any subject across the trial at that point in time.

Definition: A sequence of characters used by the sponsor to uniquely identify the study.
An abbreviation for a collection of observations, with a topic-specific commonality.
Notes: 2-character abbreviation, which must be "TM".
The type of disease milestone.
Definition of the disease milestone.
Indicates whether this is a disease milestone that can occur only once ("N") or one that can occur multiple times ("Y").

Definition: A sequence of characters used by the sponsor to uniquely identify the study.
An abbreviation for a collection of observations, with a topic-specific commonality.
Notes: 2-character abbreviation, which must be "TI".

Short name IETEST. It can be used as a column name when converting a dataset from a vertical to a horizontal format. The value in IETESTCD cannot be longer than 8 characters, nor can it start with a number (e.g., "1TEST"). IETESTCD cannot contain characters other than letters, numbers, or underscores. The prefix "IE" is used to ensure consistency with the IE domain.
Full text of the inclusion or exclusion criterion. The prefix "IE" (rather than TI) is used to ensure consistency with the IE domain.
Used for categorization of the inclusion or exclusion criterion. The prefix "IE" (rather than TI) is used to ensure consistency with the IE domain.

A further categorization of the exception criterion. Can be used to distinguish criteria for a substudy or to categorize major or minor exceptions. The prefix "IE" (rather than TI) is used to ensure consistency with the IE domain.
Rule that expresses the criterion in computer-executable form.
The number of this version of the inclusion/exclusion criteria. May be omitted if there is only 1 version.

Definition: A sequence of characters used by the sponsor to uniquely identify the study.
An abbreviation for a collection of observations, with a topic-specific commonality.
Notes: 2-character abbreviation, which must be "TS".
Sequence number to ensure uniqueness within the dataset.
Used to tie together a group of related records.

TSPARMCD (the companion to TSPARM) is limited to 8 characters and does not have special character restrictions. These values should be short for ease of use in programming, but it is not expected that TSPARMCD will need to serve as variable names.
Term for the trial summary parameter. The value in TSPARM cannot be longer than 40 characters.
Examples: "Planned Minimum Age of Subjects", "Planned Maximum Age of Subjects"

Notes: Value of TSPARM. If TSVAL is null, a value is required for TSVALNF. Text over 200 characters can be added to additional columns TSVAL1-TSVALn.
Examples: ASTHMA when TSPARM value is "Trial Indications"

Notes: Null flavor for the value of TSVAL describing the reason the value is null, to be populated only if TSVAL is null.
Code of the term in TSVAL from the reference terminology cited in TSVCDREF.
The name of the reference terminology or standard format from which TSVALCD is taken.
The version number of the reference terminology cited in TSVCDREF, if applicable.

Definition: A sequence of characters used by the sponsor to uniquely identify the study.
An abbreviation for a collection of observations, with a topic-specific commonality.
Notes: 2-character abbreviation, which must be "AC".
Sequence number given to ensure uniqueness within a dataset. Allows inclusion of multiple records for the same ACPARMCD.
Used to tie together a group of related records.

ACPARMCD (the companion to ACPARM) is limited to 8 characters and does not have special character restrictions. These values should be short for ease of use in programming, but it is not expected that ACPARMCD will need to serve as variable names.
Term for the challenge agent characterization parameter. The value in ACPARM cannot be longer than 40 characters.
Value of ACPARM.
Units for the value in ACVAL, if applicable.
Null flavor for the value of ACPARM, to be populated if and only if ACVAL is null.
This is the code of the term in ACVAL.
The name of the reference terminology from which ACVALCD is taken.
The version number of the reference terminology cited in ACVCDREF, if applicable.

Definition: A sequence of characters used by the sponsor to uniquely identify the study.
An abbreviation for a collection of observations, with a topic-specific commonality.
Notes: 2-character abbreviation, which must be "DI".
Sponsor-defined identifier for the device.
Sequence number given to ensure uniqueness within a parameter within a device (SPDEVID).
Short name of the identifier characteristic of the device.
Name of the identifier characteristic of the device.
Value for the parameter.

Definition: A sequence of characters used by the sponsor to uniquely identify the study.
An abbreviation for a collection of observations, with a topic-specific commonality.
Notes: 2-character abbreviation, which must be "OI".
Sponsor-defined identifier for a non-host organism.
Sequence number given to ensure uniqueness within a parameter within an organism (NHOID).

Variable Label: Non-Host Organism ID Element Short Name
Notes: Short name of the taxon being described.
Name of the taxon being described.
Value for the taxon in OIPARMCD/OIPARM for the organism identified by NHOID.

Definition: A sequence of characters used by the sponsor to uniquely identify the study.

Notes: 2-character abbreviation for the domain of the parent record(s).

Definition: A sequence of characters used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.

Notes: Identifier for a single associated person, a group of associated persons, or a pool of associated persons. If APID identifies a pool, POOLDEF records must exist for each associated person (see Section 6.3, Pool Definition Dataset, and Section 4, Associated Persons Data).

Definition: A sequence of characters used to uniquely identify a group of subjects that have been pooled together.
A sequence of characters used by the sponsor to uniquely identify a specific device.

Notes: Name of the identifying variable in the general-observation-class dataset that identifies the related record(s).
Value of identifying variable described in IDVAR. If --SEQ is the variable being used to describe this record, then the value of --SEQ is entered here.
