Identifies the hierarchical level of the records in the relationship. Values should be either ONE or MANY. However, values are only necessary when identifying a relationship between datasets.

RELID value should be unique within the ID variable (e.g., USUBJID, APID, POOLID, SPDEVID) that is the subject of the relationship. All records with this ID variable that have the same RELID are considered related/associated. RELID can be any value the sponsor chooses, and is only meaningful within the RELREC dataset to identify the related/associated Domain records.

Definition: A sequence of characters used by the sponsor to uniquely identify the study.

Notes: 2-character abbreviation for the domain of the parent record(s).

Definition: A sequence of characters used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.

Notes: Identifier for a single associated person, a group of associated persons, or a pool of associated persons. If APID identifies a pool, POOLDEF records must exist for each associated person (see Section 6.3, Pool Definition Dataset, and Section 4, Associated Persons Data).

Definition: A sequence of characters used to uniquely identify a group of subjects that have been pooled together.
A sequence of characters used by the sponsor to uniquely identify a specific device.

Notes: Identifying variable in the parent dataset that identifies the related record(s).
Value of identifying variable of the parent record(s).

The short name of the qualifier variable, which is used as a column name in a domain view with data from the parent domain. The value in QNAM cannot be longer than 8 characters, nor can it start with a number (e.g., "1TEST"). \n QNAM cannot contain characters other than letters, numbers, or underscores. This will often be the column name in the sponsor's operational dataset. QNAM should not be the name of any standard ADaM variable.
This is the long name or label associated with QNAM. The value in QLABEL cannot be longer than 40 characters. This will often be the column label in the sponsor's original dataset.
Result of, response to, or value associated with QNAM. A value for this column is required; no records can be in a SUPP-- dataset with a null value for QVAL.
Because QVAL can represent a mixture of collected (on a CRF), derived, or assigned items, QORIG is used to indicate the origin of this data.
Used only for results that are subjective (e.g., assigned by a person or a group). Should be null for records that contain objectively collected or derived data.

Definition: A sequence of characters used by the sponsor to uniquely identify the study.
A sequence of characters used to uniquely identify a group of subjects that have been pooled together.
Notes: Used to identify a result that is not assignable to a specific subject.

Definition: A sequence of characters used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.

Notes: Identifier for a single associated person, a group of associated persons, or a pool of associated persons.

Definition: A sequence of characters used by the sponsor to uniquely identify the study.
A sequence of characters used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.
Notes: Either USUBJID or POOLID must be populated.

Definition: A sequence of characters used to uniquely identify a group of subjects that have been pooled together.
Notes: If POOLID is entered, POOLDEF records must exist for each subject in the pool and USUBJID must be null. Either USUBJID or POOLID must be populated.
Identifier used to identify a related subject or pool of subjects. RSUBJID will be populated with either the USUBJID of the related subject or the POOLID of the related pool.
Describes the relationship of the subject identified in USUBJID or the pool identified in POOLID to the subject or pool identified in RSUBJID.

Definition: A sequence of characters used by the sponsor to uniquely identify the study.
Notes: Study identifier of the domain record(s).

Definition: An abbreviation for a collection of observations, with a topic-specific commonality.
Notes: 2-character abbreviation, which must be "DR".

Definition: A sequence of characters used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.

Notes: Sponsor-defined identifier for the device. It must be unique for each tracked unit of the device under study, and can be at whatever level of granularity the device should be identified (e.g., model or serial number, combination of identifiers) as defined in DI.

Definition: A sequence of characters used by the sponsor to uniquely identify the study.

Notes: Identifier for a single associated person, a group of associated persons, or a pool of associated persons. If APID identifies a pool, POOLDEF records must exist for each associated person (see Section 6.3, Pool Definition Dataset, and Section 4, Associated Persons Data).

Identifier for a related subject or pool of subjects. RSUBJID may be populated with the USUBJID of the related subject or the POOLID of the related pool. \n RSUBJID will be null for data about associated persons who are related to the study but not to any study subjects.
Identifier for a related device. RDEVID will be populated with the SPDEVID of the related device.

If RSUBJID is populated, describes the relationship of the associated person(s) identified in APID to the subject or pool identified in RSUBJID. \n If RDEVID is populated, describes the relationship of the associated person(s) identified in APID to the subject or pool identified in RDEVID. \n If RSUBJID and RDEVID are null, SREL describes the relationship of the associated person(s) identified in APID to the study identified in STUDYID.

Definition: A sequence of characters used by the sponsor to uniquely identify the study.
A sequence of characters used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.
A sequence of characters used to uniquely identify a source of information.
The type of sample material taken from a biological entity.

Notes: Identifies the REFID of the parent of a specimen to support tracking its genealogy.
Identifies the generation number of the sample where the collected sample is considered the first generation.
